subject: UK PM Johnson meeting with US President Trump has reportedly been suspended until June, according to The Sun
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE WEBSITE: Highlights include Japanese Securities Flows and Tertiary Industry Activity, Fed's Williams Speech
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China reported 15152 new coronavirus cases for February 12 and the death toll rose by 254 according to the National Health Commission, while Shanghai Health Commission Official noted that the methodology for the coronavirus diagnosis has not changed in areas outside the Hubei province. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said will maintain the momentum in development of the Chinese economy and will definitely be able to minimise impact from the virus outbreak, while they will also strive to achieve development targets for 2020, according to state media. (Newswires)

US President Trump said China is handling the coronavirus "professionally" according to a radio interview. Conversely, there were separate comments from NEC Director Kudlow that the US is quite disappointed in China’s nCoV response and that there does not appear to be good transparency. Kudlow added that he is disappointed that China has not accepted the invitations for assistance from the CDC and noted the US economy would be at 3% growth if it weren’t for the virus and Boeing (BA) issues. (Newswires)

US administration is said to believe China is underreporting the number of coronavirus cases by at least 100k and is "severely" under reporting the number of deaths from the virus, according to FBN's Lawrence citing sources. (Twitter)

NYT reporter tweeted that Shanghai is banning all people and cars entering the city starting midnight on February 14th due to the coronavirus, although the tweet was deleted shortly after. (Twitter)

China is reportedly considering postponing its annual parliamentary meeting (scheduled for March 5th) due to the coronavirus. (Global Times)

Japanese PM Abe said the cabinet will decide tomorrow to spend JPY 10.3bln from budget reserves to respond to the coronavirus outbreak, while it was also reported that the Japanese Health Minister confirmed the first coronavirus-related death in Japan. (Newswires)

US filed a superseding indictment on Huawei which includes a new racketeering conspiracy count and also accused the company of trade theft. (Newswires/WSJ)

India has offered to partially open its poultry and dairy markets to get a limited trade deal with the US, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson appointed Rishi Sunak as Chancellor to replace Sajid Javid who resigned, while reports noted that Javid was offered to stay on as Chancellor on condition he fired all of his advisers which he refused. (Newswires/Sky)

 

COMMODITIES

Russian Kremlin said Russia has not yet decided on further action with OPEC on oil cuts and will announce its position on deal in due course. (Newswires)

IEA Monthly Report sees Q1 global oil demand is to fall by 435k bpd Y/Y which will be first quarterly contraction in more than 10 years, while it cut 2020 oil demand growth forecast by 365k bpd to 825k bpd which is the lowest since 2011 due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

US Energy Secretary Brouillette said there has been some slowing down of Chinese energy purchases although the impact from the nCoV is marginal so far, while he suggested that if China demand is cut by 500k BPD, there will be no dramatic market impact. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

Rocket attacks have hit an airbase in Northern Iraq hosting US troops, according to AFP. (Twitter)

IRGC warned that Iran will hit Israel and the US if they make the slightest mistake. In related news, the US Navy seized weapons of “Iranian design and manufacture” in Arabian Sea bound for Iranian-backed Houthis in Yemen including anti-tank missiles, surface-to-air missiles, drone parts, weapon scopes, according to the Department of Defence. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed nominee Waller said he would cut interest rates to zero and would look to using forward guidance during the next downturn, but would not want to use negative rates in any future downturn. There were also comments from Fed nominee Shelton who said she would never support negative interest rates and would very reluctantly support QE, although reports also noted that senators expect Fed nominee Shelton to withdraw from consideration. (Newswires/The Hill)

NY Fed cuts Overnight Repo Operations limit to USD 100bln (starting Friday, prev. 120bln) and cuts Tuesday and Thursday Term repo to USD 25bln (prev. 30bln) for February and again to USD 20bln for March, while NY Fed maintained monthly Treasury Bill purchases at USD 60bln through mid-March. (Newswires)

  • US CPI (Jan) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)
  • US CPI (Jan) Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.3%)
  • US Core CPI (Jan) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.3%
  • US Real Weekly Earnings (Jan) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tape action on Thursday was essentially a paring back of the risk-off flows seen overnight after an unexpectedly large jump in reported coronavirus cases and deaths, where China cited a methodological change for the ramp higher. Risk appetite - as measured by equities, yields and crude - hit its lows in European trade before gradually clawing back into the US session; note that XAU kept its bid, whilst the DX rose back above 99.00. Cisco (CSCO) weighed on the tech sector after its report which saw poor Q3 guidance. Applied Materials (AMAT) however rose 3% following EPS and revenue beats and decent guidance, which expects to see strong double-digit growth in its semiconductor business this year. MGM (MGM) fell 5% after a heavy miss on EPS and a withdrawal of guidance as its CEO announced they are to stepdown from the company. Kraft Heinz (KHC) were hit after its figures where it’s CFO reported supply chain costs, costs of commodities and unfavourable currencies will have a 210mln negative impact on its 2020 EBITDA. SPX -0.16% at 3374, DJIA -0.43% at 29,423, NDX -0.2% at 9596.

Treasuries settled modestly bid after coming off their highs found overnight. The TPLEX found a leg higher on the sudden spike higher in nCoV cases and deaths reported out of China due to the altering of their methodology. However, yields found their lows in early European trade, alongside risk appetite, paring back most of the prior move lower through the session. A couple of factors were being cited for the reversal, one being that some drew attention to the increased reported cases being a technical adjustment that is more backward looking, supporting the thesis that China now has the virus well contained. Others cited the Gilt sell-off in the UK, following Chancellor Javid announcing his resignation, as weighing on the TPLEX and EGBs. Additionally, a slew of IG corporate issuance, including a jumbo USD 9.25bln 6-parter from Carrier Global, in addition to anticipation of the 30-year Bond auction, weighed on Fixed Income heading into the US session. The 30-year Bond auction gave some impetus behind the underlying’s bid in the later part of the session, stopping through the 2.061% WI by 0.7bps to mark the lowest ever 30-year auction, covered by 2.43x (vs six-auction avg. 2.32), while the takedown indicated strong demand as both directs and indirects took more than their averages as dealers took less. The strong auction saw the entire curve flatten by settlement, with the 30-year yield lower by 2bps and the 2yr unchanged. US T-note futures (H20) settled 2+ ticks higher at 130-24+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th February 2020: Risk assets clawback overnight losses from hike in nCov cases
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Large jump in nCoV cases amid Chinese methodology change; UK’s Javid unexpectedly resigns; US CPI inline; lowest ever 30-year Bond auction yield; NY Fed cut size of repo-operations; Banxico cut 25bps as expected
  • COMING UP: Events/Data: US Retail Sales, Uni. Of Michigan (Prelim.), Import & Export Prices, Industrial Production, Business Inventories; German GDP (Flash); Baker Hughes US Rig Count; WTI March OPEX. Speakers: Fed’s Mester. Earnings: WDI GY; AZN LN, RBS LN.

* MARKETS WRAP: Tape action on Thursday was essentially a paring back of the risk-off flows seen overnight after an unexpectedly large jump in reported coronavirus cases and deaths, where China cited a methodological change for the ramp higher. Risk appetite - as measured by equities, yields and crude - hit its lows in European trade before gradually clawing back into the US session; note that XAU kept its bid, whilst the DX rose back above 99.00. Some, of the bullish nature, drew attention to the nCoV case rises being merely a technical adjustment, as well as rather backwards-looking, alluding to the perceived containment of the virus by China. Note that the NY Fed cut its repo operations on both the overnight and term repo operations, coming at a time when recent terms have been oversubscribed, although it maintained its T-bill purchases at a clip of USD 60bln for the month ahead. Cable had a strong rally, despite some initial weakness on Chancellor Javid's surprise resignation. Looking ahead, participants now await the latest update on new cases/deaths out of China, where on the thesis that last night's big case rise was a technical glitch, expectations are for a much more modest report. On the data front, we will receive the preliminary UoM survey and US retail sales to attain insight into the US economy.

* CORONAVIRUS: The number of new cases from the coronavirus outbreak saw an unprecedented spike overnight after Chinese authorities revised standards used to count the infections. China's Hubei province reported 14,840 new coronavirus cases (under the tweaked standards) and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th, in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Reports noted Hubei authorities began using CT scans to test and diagnose patients amid shortages of RNA test kits, and today’s numbers included cases diagnosed through CT scans for the first time. That said, a Shanghai Health Commission Official noted that the methodology for coronavirus diagnosis has not changed in areas outside the Hubei province. Thus the number infected could be even more pronounced than reported. In light of this, Chinese President Xi attempted to reassure the public by stating that the country will maintain the momentum in the development of the Chinese economy, and will “definitely” be able to minimise impact from the virus outbreak, adding that the country will strive to achieve development targets for 2020. Meanwhile, US administration sources believe, as cited by FBN’s Lawrence, that China is under-reporting the number of cases by at least 100k in China, and that it is "severely" under-reporting the number of deaths. The sources added that the scientists working on how the coronavirus spreads are having difficulty getting to the site on where the first case appeared, which could help scientists determine if spreads by contact or also airborne. US NEC Director Kudlow later said the US is quite disappointed in China’s nCoV response; does not appear to be good transparency, he added. Amid the outbreak, analysts at HSBC have cut their Q1 Chinese GDP growth forecasts to 4.1% from 5.8%, with the FY forecast reduced to 5.3% from 5.8%. US Energy Secretary Brouillette said there has been some slowing down of Chinese energy purchases, although the impact from the nCoV is marginal so far, adding that if China's demand is cut by 500k BPD, there will be no dramatic market impact. 

* UK CABINET: In a surprise turn of events, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Sajid Javid resigned amid an uproar against PM Johnson, where Javid refused to fire many of his Treasury advisors, as Johnson had requested as part of his Cabinet shuffle. Briefly after, Johnson appointed the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Rishi Sunak, to the position – commentators note Sunak as a choice which would give Johnson more control over the Treasury and therefore spending ability. The initial announcement saw cable weakness, although the move swiftly reversed course, supporting a strong rally in sterling.

* US CPI (JAN): Printed 0.1% M/M, down from 0.2%, which was also the prior, whilst the Y/Y rose to 2.5% from 2.3% (vs. exp. 2.4%). The core M/M rose to 0.2% from 0.1% as expected, while the core Y/Y held at 2.3%, which had been expected to fall to 2.2%. Real weekly earnings rose by 0.1% as expected, after the prior month’s 0.1% decline. Capital Economics says that the stability of core CPI supports its view that the Fed will not be raising rates for the foreseeable future. The consultancy highlights that the 15-month high headline figure was entirely a result of base effects, noting the more meagre M/M rise falling victim to falling energy prices. The core CPI has been stable at just north of 2% for a few years, with steady growth in unit labour costs, suggesting to CapEco that it will continue that trend over the coming quarters, extrapolating that core PCE (the Fed’s preferred inflation measure) will remain “stuck firmly” below the Fed’s 2% target.

* FED: Little in the way of official commentary, but the Fed nominees Shelton and Waller faced questions in the Senate. Waller said he would cut interest rates to zero, and would look to using forward guidance during the next downturn, although would not want to use negative rates in any future downturn. Shelton, the more controversial nominees given her strong support for President Trump and previous policy commentary, said she would never support negative interest rates and would very reluctantly support QE.

* ECB: ECB’s Panetta says the protection of the environment could be considered as a secondary objective as part of the strategic review. This morning, ECB’s de Cos stated monetary policy will continue to be highly accommodative for a prolonged period of time and that a low-for-long rate environment could be spurring excessive risk-taking by some financial intermediaries.

* IEA MONTHLY REPORT: Cuts 2020 oil demand growth forecast by 365k BPD to 825k BPD citing coronavirus, the lowest since 2011. Sees Q1 global oil demand falling by 435k BPD Y/Y, the first quarterly contraction in more than 10 years. Global oil production fell by 815k BPD to 100.5mln BPD in January M/M, citing Libyan outages and reduced UAE output. OPEC crude production in January fell to 28.86mln BPD from 29.44mln BPD in December. Q1 demand for OPEC crude is set to fall to 27.2mln BPD. Non-OPEC output in January increased by 2.1mln BPD Y/Y while OPEC output contracted by a similar amount. Comparing to the other two monthly reports, OPEC downgraded their 2020 demand forecast by 230k BPD due to the coronavirus, which was in-fitting with the EIA’s assessment where they cut their respective forecast by 310k BPD. OPEC report also noted that OPEC oil lost market share yet again, whilst the EIA STEO highlighted that US crude production is poised to rise further this year.  Both reports also expected US 2020 production to rise (OPEC MOMR 13.12mln BPD; EIA STEO 13.2mln BPD) – current US record production stands at 13.0mln BPD.

* WTI (H0) SETTLES USD 0.25 HIGHER AT USD 51.42/BBL; BRENT (J0) SETTLES USD 0.55 HIGHER AT USD 56.34/BBL. The crude complex was modestly firmer on Thursday thanks to a reversal in risk appetite. The benchmarks traded in the red during the Asia session following the nCoV updates, although found a bid as US participants came to the scene, coinciding with a move higher in equity futures. The strength appeared predominantly a function of appetite/demand, whilst the Kremlin said Russia has not yet decided on further oil cuts with OPEC and said it would announce a position on the deal in due course (keeping participants waiting, again). However, some have drawn attention to the operational difficulties at Exxon’s (XOM) Baton Rouge, Louisiana refinery (500k BPD), one of the US’ largest, as perhaps providing some support to the energy markets, although the correlation of the tape action to wider risk assets draws some scepticism on the claim.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 2+ TICKS HIGHER AT 130-24+: Treasuries settled modestly bid after coming off their highs found overnight. The TPLEX found a leg higher on the sudden spike higher in nCoV cases and deaths reported out of China due to the altering of their methodology. However, yields found their lows in early European trade, alongside risk appetite, paring back most of the prior move lower through the session. A couple of factors were being cited for the reversal, one being that some drew attention to the increased reported cases being a technical adjustment that is more backward looking, supporting the thesis that China now has the virus well contained. Others cited the Gilt sell-off in the UK, following Chancellor Javid announcing his resignation, as weighing on the TPLEX and EGBs. Additionally, a slew of IG corporate issuance, including a jumbo USD 9.25bln 6-parter from Carrier Global, in addition to anticipation of the 30-year Bond auction, weighed on Fixed Income heading into the US session. The 30-year Bond auction gave some impetus behind the underlying’s bid in the later part of the session, stopping through the 2.061% WI by 0.7bps to mark the lowest ever 30-year auction, covered by 2.43x (vs six-auction avg. 2.32), while the takedown indicated strong demand as both directs and indirects took more than their averages as dealers took less. The strong auction saw the entire curve flatten by settlement, with the 30-year yield lower by 2bps and the 2yr unchanged.

* NY FED REPO SCHEDULE: In the latest NY Fed month ahead schedule, it cut its O/N Repo Operations limit to USD 100bln (starting Friday, prev. 120bln); cut Tuesday and Thursday Term repo operations to USD 25bln (prev. 30bln) for February and again to USD 20bln for March. The NY FED also maintained its monthly treasury bill purchases at USD 60bln through the middle of March.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.16% at 3374, DJIA -0.43% at 29,423, NDX -0.2% at 9596. SECTORS: Cons Disc -0.24%, Cons Stpl +0.55%, Energy -0.45%, Financials -0.04%, Health -0.54%, Industrials -0.69%, Materials -0.38%, Real Estate +0.5%, Technology -0.3%, Communication Svs +0.15%, Utilities +1%.

* EARNINGS: Cisco (CSCO) weighed on the tech sector after its report which saw poor Q3 guidance. Applied Materials (AMAT) however rose 3% following EPS and revenue beats and decent guidance, which expects to see strong double-digit growth in its semiconductor business this year. MGM (MGM) fell 5% after a heavy miss on EPS and a withdrawal of guidance as its CEO announced they are to stepdown from the company. Kraft Heinz (KHC) were hit after its figures where it’s CFO reported supply chain costs, costs of commodities and unfavourable currencies will have a 210mln negative impact on its 2020 EBITDA.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: A US court granted Amazon (AMZN) a temporary halt to the DoD JEDI USD 10bln cloud contract with Microsoft (MSFT) following Amazon’s suit. The headline saw immediate weakness in MSFT shares and slight upside in AMZN, however AMZN gains were short-lived as it tracked the broader market sell off heading into the tail end of US cash trade. Elsewhere, Foxconn (2354 TT) announced that reports regarding its China plant resumption is not factual. The recent reports suggested it reopened its China plant but only 10% came back to work, other reports noted its Shenzhen facility had now been allowed to reopen, with China production expected to return to 50% in February, and 80% in March. DigiTimes reported Apple (AAPL) demand for Taiwan Semiconductors (TSMC) 5nm A14 chips is likely to be high to support Apple’s 5G devices. The publication also reported it is likely to stick with its plans to unveil its next-generation iPhone in September as normal despite the potential delay to the release of its cheaper model due to the coronavirus, although it suggested Apple suppliers (QRVO, Avago) have begun full production of device components for the iPhone SE 2. Southwest Airlines (LUV) announced it is proactively removing the Boeing (BA) 737 MAX jet from its flight schedule through August 10th. Tesla (TSLA) ended firmer despite initial reports that it is recalling 15k Model X SUV’s and that it received a subpoena from the SEC. TSLA announced a USD 2bln stock offering which initially added to the weakness, however as investors digested the stock offering, TSLA surged wiping out pre-market losses and closed ~4% higher on the day. In M&A, T-Mobile (TMUS) parent, Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY), announced it is looking to renegotiate the merger terms between TMUS and Sprint (S), given the poor performance in Sprint, recently.

* BANXICO: The central bank cut its interest rate by 25bps as expected, making it the for the 5th consecutive rate cut. The decision this time was however unanimous, despite Esquivel opting for a 50bp rate cut at the last two meetings. On growth, Banxico noted balance of risks remain tilted to the downside and that 2020 GDP is expected to grow less than expected, and Governor De Leon announced it would be downgrading its economic growth forecast in the next quarterly report. On inflation, the bank noted that headline and core inflation are expected to be moderately higher than previous forecasts, thus heading further away from its 3% inflation target, however the bank noted that lower energy prices due to the coronavirus is a downside inflation risk.

* FX WRAP: EUR continued its demise with EURUSD breaking yesterday’s low and key fib level at 109.64, to continue its fall through 108.50. The fall comes amid a lack of a fresh catalyst but continues to be taking its cue from familiar arguments: weak EU data, improved conditions for a carry trade and German political woes. USD hovered around the 99.00 figure throughout the session with US CPI doing little to sway price action. The buck, however, fell beneath the key figure in overnight trade as JPY caught a bid as the coronavirus cases increased drastically in the Hubei province, although the greenback clawed back gains and ended firmer on the day. USDJPY dropped to lows of 109.63 throughout the session after the nCoV developments as the cross saw one-way trade, before residing at 109.80 through the tail end of the session. GBP saw choppy trade, sterling traded firmer in the morning but the resignation of Chancellor Javid saw initial downside, although the losses were quickly faded and Cable continued its rally throughout the rest of the session before calming at the 1.3050 with some suggestions that the new appointee, Rishi Sunak, is more disposed to fiscal spending. Technical factors also at play as Cable crossed its 15 and 21 dma, at 1.3012 and 1.3028, respectively, before finding resistance at the 50dma at 1.3071. XAU traded firmer up to the 1575 handle once again following the large jump in coronavirus cases overnight which saw Antipodes give up some of the prior day gains, failing to pare as other risk assets did. EMFX was generally weaker against the buck with weakness particularly seen in RUB. Strength, however, was seen in BRL following central bank intervention to stem the recent Real losses. TRY traded relatively flat against the buck amid decent Turkish industrial production data. The Banxico rate decision saw little in way of MXN price action, although USDMXN fell gradually towards the tail end of the session despite a dovish outlook, although the decision saw Esquivel, who previously opted for a 50bp cut, join the 25bp camp. The statement also expressed concerns on inflation running away from target, which could lead members to lean less dovish in the future. Note, SocGen heading into the announcement highlighted that current market pricing is currently the most aggressive across the globe with over 100bps worth of easing priced in over the next 12 months.

analysis_details: Treasuries settled modestly bid after coming off their highs found overnight. The TPLEX found a leg higher on the sudden spike higher in nCoV cases and deaths reported out of China due to the altering of their methodology. However, yields found their lows in early European trade, alongside risk appetite, paring back most of the prior move lower through the session. A couple of factors were being cited for the reversal, one being that some drew attention to the increased reported cases being a technical adjustment that is more backward looking, supporting the thesis that China now has the virus well contained. Others cited the Gilt sell-off in the UK, following Chancellor Javid announcing his resignation, as weighing on the TPLEX and EGBs. Additionally, a slew of IG corporate issuance, including a jumbo USD 9.25bln 6-parter from Carrier Global, in addition to anticipation of the 30-year Bond auction, weighed on Fixed Income heading into the US session. The 30-year Bond auction gave some impetus behind the underlying’s bid in the later part of the session, stopping through the 2.061% WI by 0.7bps to mark the lowest ever 30-year auction, covered by 2.43x (vs six-auction avg. 2.32), while the takedown indicated strong demand as both directs and indirects took more than their averages as dealers took less. The strong auction saw the entire curve flatten by settlement, with the 30-year yield lower by 2bps and the 2yr unchanged.

analysis_details:
• CRUDE: The crude complex was modestly firmer on Thursday thanks to a reversal in risk appetite. The benchmarks traded in the red during the Asia session following the nCoV updates, although found a bid as US participants came to the scene, coinciding with a move higher in equity futures. The strength appeared predominantly a function of appetite/demand, whilst the Kremlin said Russia has not yet decided on further oil cuts with OPEC and said it would announce a position on the deal in due course (keeping participants waiting, again). However, some have drawn attention to the operational difficulties at Exxon’s (XOM) Baton Rouge, Louisiana refinery (500k BPD), one of the US’ largest, as perhaps providing some support to the energy markets, although the correlation of the tape action to wider risk assets draws some scepticism on the claim.

 

  • IEA MONTHLY REPORT: Cuts 2020 oil demand growth forecast by 365k BPD to 825k BPD citing coronavirus, the lowest since 2011. Sees Q1 global oil demand falling by 435k BPD Y/Y, the first quarterly contraction in more than 10 years. Global oil production fell by 815k BPD to 100.5mln BPD in January M/M, citing Libyan outages and reduced UAE output. OPEC crude production in January fell to 28.86mln BPD from 29.44mln BPD in December. Q1 demand for OPEC crude is set to fall to 27.2mln BPD. Non-OPEC output in January increased by 2.1mln BPD Y/Y while OPEC output contracted by a similar amount. Comparing to the other two monthly reports, OPEC downgraded their 2020 demand forecast by 230k BPD due to the coronavirus, which was in-fitting with the EIA’s assessment where they cut their respective forecast by 310k BPD. OPEC report also noted that OPEC oil lost market share yet again, whilst the EIA STEO highlighted that US crude production is poised to rise further this year.  Both reports also expected US 2020 production to rise (OPEC MOMR 13.12mln BPD; EIA STEO 13.2mln BPD) – current US record production stands at 13.0mln BPD.

PRIMER: Banxico rate decision on Thursday 13th February at 19:00 GMT / 14:00 ET
analysis_details:
The Street expects the central bank to cut its rate by 25bs, taking its key rate to 7%, as expected by 22 of the 23 analysts surveyed by Reuters, with the outlier expecting Banxico to stand pat. Inflation has recently ticked up above the mid-point of its target range, however the recent fall in oil prices may help with the core figures. 

EXPECTATIONS:

  • At its previous meeting, only one member, Esquivel, opted for a 50bp rate cut, where Heath only voted for a 25bps cut, despite previously sitting in the 50bp camp with Esquivel. TD highlight that despite this “we actually see an increasing risk that a 50bp rate cut is considered as there appears to be more room now to do so than at any point in the easing cycle”. The desk however sees the bank moving at a steady rate of cuts but expects markets to be more surprised by Banxico dovishness, due to current rate pricing, which TD believes is substantially underpricing Banxico’s easing cycle. SocGen highlight that current market pricing is currently the most aggressive across the globe with over 100bps worth of easing priced in over the next 12 months.

RECENT DATA:

  • Consumer prices were up from 2.8% Y/Y to 3.2% January, missing the Street's 3.3% view, although slightly above the banks 3% target. Non-core inflation drove prices higher, mainly due to higher goods prices, and despite the stability of the MXN in Q4. "The main driver here was the processed food and tobacco components, hit by higher IEPS taxes," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "these pressures will ease soon”. Services was relatively unchanged, with the effects of the new minimum wage earlier in the month, as well as consumer inertia, perhaps easing some of the Banxico's fears; Pantheon writes that Mexico’s inflation is under control, despite January's headline increase, which was mainly due to by one-off factors, and it expects the underlying trend to ease gradually towards Banxico’s 3% target in Q2. "Domestic inflation pressures remain subdued, and the MXN's rebound since August supports our forecast of a benign core inflation picture over the next three-to-six months," PM writes, "moreover, the recent fall in oil prices will help to keep noncore pressures in check during Q2, and accordingly, we think Banxico will continue to cut interest rates over the first half of the year."

MINUTES/ RECENT COMMENTARY:

  • The latest minutes saw all board members expecting weakness in the economy in Q4, noting it is still stagnant. On inflation, the majority believed that core inflation has been persistent and that upside for inflation has appeared, which could potentially make it a challenge to attain its 3% target for 2020 following the increase in its minimum wage.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling soars, Euro slides and Dollar side-lined
content:
GBP/EUR

Not quite as dramatic or constructive as BoE super Thursday, but certainly a return to winning ways after last week’s disappointing penultimate trading session when Brexit qualms returned to plague the Pound. Indeed, Cable has rebounded strongly to eclipse 1.3050 and test last Tuesday’s 1.3070 peak ahead of 1.3081 Fib resistance after a knee-jerk blip on news that Sajid Javid rejected the offer to remain as UK Chancellor in PM Johnson’s new cabinet due to the contingent demand that he returned to the role without any of his advisers. By all accounts, Johnson and Javid had a heated exchange before the latter quit and the former quickly appointed Rishi Sunak said to be the man favoured by Downing Street strategist Dominic Cummings and someone more disposed to fiscal spending. In stark contrast, the Euro has endured a rough ride as a key Fib gave way at 1.0864 and 1.0850 barriers vs the Dollar were subsequently breached to leave Eur/Gbp dangling precariously above 0.8300. The single currency continues to weaken on a combination of bearish factors, including carry trades, downbeat economic indicators and obviously ever increasing technical.

JPY

The other major outperformer even though risk sentiment via stocks and similar high-beta or sensitive assets appeared to abate over the course of the (EU) day and the Greenback retained a firm underlying bid overall. Usd/Jpy has been skirting the base of a 110.09-109.63 range for the most part despite the DXY holding a relatively tight line around 99.000 and actually notching a fresh 99.105 peak, mainly at the expense of G10 rivals and the bulk of EMs.

CHF/CAD/AUD/NZD

All softer vs the Buck, with the Franc slipping closeogyr to 0.9800, but still on an upward trajectory against the aforementioned depreciating Euro as 1.0600 approaches (to possibly arouse SNB interest). Meanwhile, the non-US Dollars have slipped from best levels within 1.3240-70, 0.6745-08 and 0.6466-29 respective ranges for the Loonie, Aussie and Kiwi, but have been cushioned by BoC, RBA and RBNZ commentary essentially underscoring steady near term rate outlooks and comparatively upbeat economic assessments, barring severe fall-out from China’s nCoV.

EM

Choppy trade for many regional currencies and mostly losses vs the Usd, but the Cnh and Cny displayed some resilience after the overnight revelations regarding the vastly higher Hubei infection tally using new methodology. Elsewhere, the Try and Zar gleaned traction to varied extent from decent Turkish ip and SA mining production updates, but the Brl really managed to stop the rot via the BCB announcing an FX swap auction after the Real slumped to new all time lows. Ahead, Banxico rate call for the Mxn to digest and a 25 bp cut widely expected, so guidance key for Peso direction.

analysis_details: US indices opened in negative territory, however futures have pared back a large portion of overnight losses which was spurred by a drastic increase in nCoV cases as the reporting measures were revised to include CT scans, which saw over 14800 new cases and over 200 newly reported deaths. Although the rebound had stalled amid source reports US administration officials believe that China is understating cases by over 100k. Most sectors opened in negative territory, apart from Real Estate and Utilities, due to the defensive nature of the sectors. Real Estate lead gains boosted by earnings from Iron Mountain (IRM) who outperformed in the SPX at the open. Materials also opened higher. On the flip side, Cyclicals underperformed which saw Industrials and Technology the laggards, with Industrials weighed on by earnings from Huntington Ingalls (HII) and Waste Management (WM), while Cisco (CSCO) losses weighed on Technology.

analysis_details: • The Street looks for CPI rise to 2.4% Y/Y from 2.3% and remain at 0.2% M/M though the core metric is seen picking up to 0.2% M/M from December's 0.1%. UBS sees the headline picking up to 2.4%, a notable pick-up from the 1.7% seen in September. However, the bank says that falling oil prices mean the January reading will likely be the peak, and then sees CPI inflation easing towards around 1.6% by April. UBS sees the core measure staying in a 2.2-2.3% range through the Summer. In contrast, however, the bank sees the core PCE gauge of inflation, the Fed's preferred measure, picking up a bit more strongly than core CPI, moving towards 1.9% in February before easing in the Spring. Nonetheless, the Fed has stressed in recent commentary its aversion to any rate hikes unless inflation was to sustainably sit above its target, so how much sway the print will have on near-term Fed policy remains limited.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards – the methodology has not changed outside Hubei
  • European stocks trade with losses across the board [Eurostoxx 50 -1.4%], FTSE 100 underperforms
  • Risk aversion sees safe-haven FX bid, DXY is softer below 99.000 and energy futures decline
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims, Banxico Rate Decision, Fed’s Williams, ECB’s Lane & Panetta, supply from the US, UK Cabinet Reshuffle

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th, in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Furthermore, reports noted Hubei authorities began using CT scans to test and diagnose patients amid shortages of RNA test kits and today’s numbers included cases diagnosed through CT scans for the first time. (Newswires/Twitter)

Shanghai Health Commission Official notes that the methodology for coronavirus diagnosis has not changed in areas outside the Hubei province. (Newswires)

The Chinese Institute of Certified Public Accountants is in close talks with relevant authorities, raising the postponement of annual fiscal report disclosure, citing uncertainty resulting from coronavirus. (Newswires)

Japan confirmed another 44 coronavirus cases from the cruise ship off Yokohama. In related news, Japanese PM Abe adviser Hamada said Japan would need fiscal support if there is a hard impact from coronavirus. Furthermore, Japanese government 'virus package' is expected to include certain help for companies and stronger testing related to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Hong Kong postponed the resumption of schools to March 16th from March 2nd due to coronavirus, while the Taiwan Cabinet is said to propose a special budget of TWD 60bln for support amid impact from coronavirus. (Newswires)

Vietnam reportedly quarantined a commune of 10k people due to coronavirus, according to AFP. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded cautiously as the euphoria from the record highs on Wall St were soured by a significant jump in the number of additional coronavirus cases. The Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 more deaths as of February 12th in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.2%) remained afloat with a slew of earnings the main driver for the biggest movers in the index including Big 4 bank NAB and with TPG Telecom bolstered after the federal court approved its merger with Vodafone Hutchison Australia, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) succumbed to the flows into the JPY and as participants also digested quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were subdued amid uncertainty following the surge in confirmed cases and although some suggested the number would have been less than the prior day without the adjustments, the number of new fatalities more than doubled. Finally, 10yr JGBs were choppy amid the cautious risk tone and after the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.2tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities, did little to spur demand for the benchmark.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9785 vs. Exp. 6.9787 (Prev. 6.9718)

China replaced the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office head, while the Hubei Province Party Secretary and Wuhan Communist Party chief were also removed from duty. (Newswires)

China's Defence Ministry said it strongly condemned US actions on indictments against China military personnel related to the Equifax case, while it urged the US to correct its mistakes and rescind the indictments. (Newswires)

UK/EU

As a reminder, UK PM Johnson will today announce his cabinet reshuffle, however, speculation suggests that changes are likely to be limited. (Newswires)

ECB's de Cos says monetary policy will continue to be highly accommodative for a prolonged period of time. (Newswires)

 

German CPI Final YY* (Jan) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%); MM* (Jan) -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.6% (Prev. -0.6%)

-        HICP Final YY* (Jan) 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.6%); MM* (Jan) -0.8% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. -0.8%)

European Commission Economic Forecasts - Real GDP: EZ: 2019 1.2% (Prev. 1.1%); 2020 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%); 2021 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%) - Inflation: EZ: 2020 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%); 2021 1.4% (Prev. 1.3%)

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said the senate should not vote for the Iran war powers resolution and suggested that the US is doing very well with Iran and this is not the time to show weakness, while he added that Iran would have a field day if his hands were tied which sends a very bad signal. (Newswires) 

EQUITIES

European stocks trade with losses across the board [Eurostoxx 50 -1.4%] following on from a similar APAC handover, as sentiment took a blow following an unprecedented rise in COVID-19 cases after an adjustment to standards. Bourses are firmly in the red, with the FTSE 100 (-1.7%) underperforming regional peers amid a slew of factors including losses in large-cap miners, oil giants and heavyweight financials. Market contacts highlighted notable selling program triggered for Eurostoxx 50 futures and a technical break below yesterday’s low in the DAX exacerbated downside. Sectors are largely lower but reflect risk aversion as defensive fare modestly better than cyclicals, with materials and energy sectors underperforming amid price action in their respective complexes. Back to the FTSE, Barclays (-2.0%) shares fell post-earnings after the Co. noted that it would be challenging to reach a 2020 ROTE of over 10%, while UK regulators opened a probe into CEO Staley’s link to Jeffrey Epstein. Meanwhile, miners bear the brunt of declines across the base metal markets – with Antofagasta (-1.7%), Glencore (-1.9%) and BHP (-0.8%) all lower. Similarly, oil giants feel downward pressure from the price action in the energy complex, albeit BP (-2.9%) and Shell (-3.0%) also trade ex-div today. Elsewhere, SMI-heavyweight Nestle (-2.3%) shares fell after missing revenue and organic sales growth forecasts whilst also halting the production of its low-sugar brand due to coronavirus’ impact. Note: Nestle has ~19% weighting in the SMI and ~3.2% weighing in the Stoxx600. Credit Suisse (-0.7%) shares fell with the broader market after initially seeing some reprieve from earnings after posting a 69% jump in annual net profit despite the spying scandal. Other earnings-related movers include Orange (+1.9%), Centrica (-16%), Zurich Insurance (+0.7%), Clariant (+4.9%) and Pernod Ricard (+1.7%)

FX

JPY/CHF/XAU/DXY - The traditional safe-havens are back in demand and outperforming, as revised classification standards used to determine whether an individual has contracted the coronavirus at the source in Hubei has hugely inflated the number of confirmed cases and reignited concerns about the overall tally and contagion, especially if the new methodology is rolled out to other provinces. In response, the Yen is back above 110.00, the Franc is nearer 0.9750 than 0.9800 and Gold is back up around Usd 1575/oz from circa Usd 1560 at one stage yesterday, while the Dollar has pulled back accordingly.

GBP/EUR - Sterling remains relatively resilient in the face of the downturn in broad risk sentiment, albeit partly due to the Greenback losing momentum, as noted above, and the Euro continuing to depreciate amidst weak fundamentals and more outflows against currencies that are costlier to fund. However, Cable is still capped ahead of 1.3000 and the 10 DMA (1.2984 today) that was matched, but not surpassed and Eur/Gbp has not spiralled down through 0.8400 as Eur/Usd holds just above key Fib support (1.0864), for now at least.

USD - The DXY has slipped a bit further from Wednesday’s new multi-month high (99.052 to 98.852) on the aforementioned deterioration in risk appetite that has boosted the Jpy, Chf and Xau, though the index and Buck overall remains underpinned ahead of US CPI, weekly claims and more Fed speak via Williams. Technically, 99.249 forms nearest chart resistance, while support resides down at 98.544.

CAD/NZD/AUD/NOK/SEK - The Loonie has lost its crude prop, but is gleaning enough support to hold around 1.3250 after comments from BoC Governor Poloz reiterating the cons of looser monetary policy and claiming that Canada’s economy is in a good place, while the Kiwi is consolidating off post-RBNZ peaks circa 0.6450 following Deputy Governor Hawkesby underlining a genuine neutral stance and the Aussie is acknowledging RBA Governor Lowe reiterating a wait-and-see bias given no rush to get inflation back to target as Aud/Usd meanders in the low 0.6700+ area and Aud/Nzd pivots 1.0425. Ahead, NZ manufacturing PMI and food prices. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Crown is naturally more attune to a dip in oil prices, but its Swedish peer is also wary about a return to risk aversion.

EM - Widespread declines vs the Dollar including the Yuan for obvious reasons, but also the Lira even though Turkish ip beat consensus and the Rand regardless of a more pronounced recovery in SA mining production. Similary, the Mexican Peso is on the back foot awaiting the anticipated 25 bp Banxico rate cut later today.

Bank of Canada Governor Poloz said the Canadian economy is in a pretty good place and suggested that lowering rates could increase risks from higher debt levels. (Newswires)

RBA Governor Lowe said outlook in Australia is improving but added that coronavirus is having an uncertain impact and noted that Chinese policy stimulus will be good for Australia. Furthermore, RBA Governor Lowe said low interest rates are working and are going to take time, while he added they are not obsessed with getting inflation back to target in a hurry. (Newswires)

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said the RBNZ has a genuine neutral bias but is open to review that in light of developments, while he added that the impact from coronavirus expected to be modest but will review it if travel restrictions are prolonged or virus is more widespread. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

It remains to be seen whether the latest bounce in bonds lasts or extends beyond recent peaks that are proving impervious, but the current revival has been more compelling in outright price terms given that Bunds reached 174.64, Gilts 134.32 and 10 year US T-notes 131-05+ before topping out. In contrast, EU equities have pared some declines ahead of the US open and data that may divert attention from all things China virus outbreak related for a while, then the 30 year auctions and a speech from Fed’s Williams.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures have erased a bulk of the prior session’s gains, with prices south of 51/bbl and 55.50/bbl respectively, as the unexpected jump in coronavirus cases sparked risked aversion, while no sense of urgency from Russia regarding output action also adds to the bearish narrative. Further on the OPEC front, Kremlin stated that Moscow has not yet decided on further action with OPEC on oil cuts, adding that it will announce a deal in due course – as a reminder, the Russian Energy Ministry met with domestic oil producers yesterday with some comments alluding to most Russian companies wanting the cuts to be continued for one more quarter. Elsewhere, the IEA monthly oil report downgraded its 2020 demand growth forecast by 365k BPD – the deepest among the three oil market reports, citing impacts of the coronavirus on demand. This follows OPEC and EIA slashing their respective 2020 global oil demand growth forecasts by 230k BPD and 310k BPD. Elsewhere, spot gold retains an underlying bid amid the risk-off sentiment with prices meandering 1575/oz. Conversely, copper sees sentiment-driven losses with prices back below 2.6/lb after briefly reclaiming the level.

IEA Monthly Report: cuts 2020 oil demand growth forecast by 365k bpd to 825k bpd citing coronavirus; lowest since 2011. (Newswires)

Russian Kremlin says Russia has not yet decided on further action with OPEC on oil cuts and will announce position on deal in due course. (Newswires)

Libyan oil output stands at 191,475bpd as of Wednesday February 12th, according to the NOC. (Newswires)

content:
• Q1 global oil demand is to fall by 435k bpd Y/Y; first quarterly contraction in more than 10 years.
  • Global oil production fell by 815k bpd to 100.5mln bpd in January M/M; cites Libyan outages and reduced UAE output
  • OPEC crude production in January fell to 28.86mln bpd from 29.44mln bpd in December
  • Q1 demand for OPEC crude is set to fall to 27.2mln bpd.
  • Non-OPEC output in January increased by 2.1mln bpd Y/Y while OPEC output contracted by a similar amount.
  • Link to report here
analysis_details:
• OPEC downgraded their 2020 demand forecast by 230k bpd due to the coronavirus, which was in-fitting with the EIA’s assessment where they cut their respective forecast by 310k BPD.
  • OPEC report also noted that OPEC oil lost market share yet again, whilst the EIA STEO highlighted that US crude production is poised to rise further this year.  Both reports also expected US 2020 production to rise (OPEC MOMR 13.12mln BPD; EIA STEO 13.2mln BPD) – current US record production stands at 13.0mln BPD

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures follow bullish leads, with one eye on reshuffle
content: In the absence of anything new on the home front until PM Johnson unveils his new cabinet line up (and even then the appointments are not expected to impact domestic markets), UK debt and STIR contracts are conforming to the markedly more positive tone elsewhere after recent declines on a combination of safe-haven unwinding and better than expected data underpinning the BoE’s less dovish stance and near term policy guidance than many anticipated. The catalyst for the change in mood and direction is mainly due to a reassessment of the Chinese outbreak situation as revised methodology at the epicentre has resulted in a significantly higher contamination tally. Looking at Liffe price action, Gilts are holding within 134.07-21 parameters vs Wednesday’s 133.76 close and the 3 month strip is 0.5-2 ticks ahead.

subject: Bunds: paring some recovery gains, but still firmly bid

Core bonds are also gleaning traction from the 2nd US refunding leg that was well received hot on the heels of Germany’s new 2030 offering that drew solid demand, while eyeing the reaction across EU stock indices to gauge the level of contagion and spill-over to broad risk sentiment. Ahead, several ECB speakers, including Chief Economist Lane at 2 separate events and more supply via Italy’s multi-tranche offering, US 30 year TIPs and long bonds.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th February 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded cautious as the euphoria from the record highs on Wall St, where participants found solace from hopes of a slowdown in the coronavirus outbreak, was soured by a significant jump in the number of additional cases at the epicentre of the outbreak. The Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 more deaths as of February 12th in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.2%) remained afloat with a slew of earnings the main driver for the biggest movers in the index including Big 4 bank NAB and with TPG Telecom bolstered after the federal court approved its merger with Vodafone Hutchison Australia, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) succumbed to the flows into the JPY and as participants also digested quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were subdued amid uncertainty following the surge in confirmed cases and although some suggested the number would have been less than the prior day without the adjustments, the number of new fatalities more than doubled.

FTSE 100

EX-DIVS: (BP BP/ LN), Hargreaves Landsdown (HRGV LN) , Polymetal International (POLY LN) and (Shell RDSA LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 11.7 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – Is seeking to cut the price of T-Mobiles’ (TMUS) takeover of Sprint (S) as they feel that the price, which was agreed two years ago, is too large given the deterioration in Sprint’s performance and share prices. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Commerzbank (CBK GY) – Q4 net EUR -54mln vs. Exp. EUR -99mln, operating profit EUR 250mln vs. Prev. EUR 240mln, revenue EUR 2.173bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.035bln. FY19 pre-tax profit EUR 1.112bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.227bln, revenue EUR 8.64bln vs. Prev. EUR 8.57bln, operating profit EUR 1.26bln; described as being stable. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – FY19 revenue EUR 70.48bln vs. Exp. EUR 70.23bln. Adj. EBIT EUR 6.95bln vs. Exp. EUR 6.83bln. Dividend EUR 1.80 vs. Exp. EUR 2.05. Q4 adj. EBIT EUR 2.81bln vs. Exp, EUR 2.7bln. Q4 revenue EUR 24.3bln vs. Exp. EUR 23.3bln. Adj. EBIT margin 11.5% vs. Prev. 13.3%. Co. sees 2020 deliveries at ~800. Co. notes that FY19 targets were achieved and 2020 guidance is to set path for sustainable growth. In 2020, group sees world air traffic to grow in-line with prevailing independent forecasts, which assumes no major disruptions including from the coronavirus outbreak. Separately, Co. and the govern,ent of Quebec have become the sole owners of the A220 programme (for USD 591mln) as Bombardier completes its strategic exit from commercial aviation. Airbus is said to be negotiating a major preliminary order for A220s, according to sources. (Newswires) This follows last week’s reports that Airbus is in advanced discussions to buy Bombardier remaining stake in the two companies’ A220 commercial jetliner JV, according to sources cited by WSJ. NOTE: Airbus has a 2.5% weighting in the CAC40, ~0.9% weighting in the Stoxx600 and ~2.9% in the Euro Stoxx 50.

Legrand (LR FP) - FY 2019 revenue EUR 6.62bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.99bln, FY 2019 net EUR 834.8mln vs. Prev. EUR 771.7mln and adjusted operating profit EUR 1.32bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.21bln. (Newswires)

Orange (ORA FP) - FY 2019 revenue EUR 42.2bln vs. Exp. EUR 42bln, EBITDA EUR 12.9bln vs. Exp. EUR 12.9bln. Co. raises Telecom cash flow target and confirms 2020 goals. Co. proposes dividend of EUR 0.7/shr. Co. says 2020 EBIT will be “flat/positive”. Co. said it launched this week the process to find financial partner for Orange concessions. Co. says its too early to evaluate costs of Mobile World Congress cancellation. (Newswires)

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) - H1 revenue EUR 5.47bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.19bln, operating profit EUR 1.79bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.75bln and net EUR 1.05bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.04bln. (Newswires)

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – Co. have made a EUR 1.4bln offer for RIB Software (RIB GY), which equates to EUR 29/shr. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Rexel (RXL FP) - FY 19 revenue EUR 13.7bln vs. Prev. EUR 13.8bln, adj. EBITDA EUR 685.1mln vs. Prev. EUR 652.0mln, net EUR 341.2mln vs. Exp. EUR 345.3mln. CEO says performance was inline with 2019 guidance. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE 

ABN AMRO (ABN NA) – Are to review their corporate and investment banking activities following a sharp loan increase. (FT)

NN Group (NN NA) – Q4 net EUR 329mln vs. Prev. EUR -533mln (this did include a goodwill impairment), operating result EUR 428mln vs. Prev. EUR 343mln. FY19 dividend total of EUR 2.16/shr. Co. are to complete their EUR 250mln share buyback programme within the next 12-months. (Newswires)

Telecom Names – The Swiss Government has placed an indefinite moratorium on 5G towers, of which they have over 2000 antennas, due to health concerns. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Nestle (NESN SW) – FY19 Revenue CHF 92.6bln vs. Exp. CHF 93.3bln. Organic sales growth 3.5% vs. exp. 3.6% Net 12.6bln vs. Prev. CHF 10.1bln. Operating profit CHF 16.3bln vs. Prev. CHF 15.5bln. Co. commenced a new share buyback programme of CHF 20bln for 2020. Co. continued to increase in organic sales growth in 2020. EPS increased by 28% YY to CHF 4.30 on a reported basis. Underlying EPS and return to shareholders reached record levels. Co. notes that it is too early to quantify the impact from the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires) Co. has stopped production of its new low-sugar brand after low demand. (BBC). NOTE: Co. has ~19% weighting in the SMI, and ~3.2% weighing in the Stoxx600

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – Q4 revenue CHF 6.19bln vs. Exp. CHF 5.56bln. Net income CHF 852mln vs. Exp. CHF 934mln. FY dividend CHF 0.2776 vs. Exp. CHF 0.2820. ROTE 9% vs. 5% YY. Co. commenced a share buyback programmed for 2020, expected to buy back at least CHF 1bln of shares – contingent on market and economic conditions. Incoming CEO Gottstein says he is firmly committed to ambitions set out at 2019 investor day. Co. says the year started on a strong footing across all divisions and remain cautiously optimistic. (Newswires) NOTE: Co. has a 3% weighting in the SMI

Zurich Insurance (ZURN SW) – FY19 net USD 4.15bln vs. Exp. CHF 4.03bln. Co. raises dividend to CHF 20/shr. Guides initially FY20 to deliver further improvement in underwriting performance in P&C. Gross written premium USD 34.18bln vs. Prev. USD 33.5bln. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

*CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.64% at 3379, DJIA +0.9% at 29,551, NDX +1% at 9613. SECTORS: Cons Disc +0.99%, Cons Stpl -0.04%, Energy +1.36 %, Financials +0.07%, Health +0.14%, Industrials +0.92%, Materials +0.52%, Real Estate +0.67%, Technology +1.06%, Communication Svs +1.25%, Utilities +0.02%.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th
  • Asian equity markets traded cautiously as the euphoria from the record highs on Wall St were soured by the latest updates from Hubei
  • DXY stalled after printing fresh 3-month highs above the 99.00 level where it met resistance to provide some much-needed reprieve for EUR/USD
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that the implementation of the mini-trade deal with China has slowed down due to the nCoV
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (F), US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims, Banxico Rate Decision & IEA Monthly Oil Report, Fed’s Williams, ECB’s Lane & Panetta, supply from Italy and the US, UK Cabinet Reshuffle
  • Earnings: PepsiCo, Linde, Fidelity, AIG, Kraft Heinz, Airbus, ThyssenKrupp, Commerzbank, Barclays, Credit Suisse

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th, in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Furthermore, reports noted Hubei authorities began using CT scans to test and diagnose patients amid shortages of RNA test kits and today’s numbers included cases diagnosed through CT scans for the first time. (Newswires/Twitter)

WHO said the number of newly confirmed coronavirus cases declined steadily for the past week but added that it must be interpreted with extreme caution and that the outbreak could still go in any direction. (Newswires)

CDC said it was seeing "fewer and fewer" travellers from China and no new cases at US airports, while it added new controls to avoid testing mishaps with the coronavirus and is likely to see some "community spread" in the US. (Newswires)

Japan confirmed another 44 coronavirus cases from the cruise ship off Yokohama. In related news, Japanese PM Abe adviser Hamada said Japan would need fiscal support if there is a hard impact from coronavirus. Furthermore, Japanese government 'virus package' is expected to include certain help for companies and stronger testing related to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Hong Kong postponed the resumption of schools to March 16th from March 2nd due to coronavirus, while the Taiwan Cabinet is said to propose a special budget of TWD 60bln for support amid impact from coronavirus. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin does not expect the coronavirus to have an impact on economic growth beyond this year, while he talked with Fed Chair Powell on the global economic impact of coronavirus and agreed it's too soon to say what the impact will be. Furthermore, Mnuchin added that the implementation of the mini-trade deal with China has slowed down due to the nCoV and that the entire "chapters" of Phase Two have been "dealt with". (Newswires)

Vietnam reportedly quarantined a commune of 10k people due to coronavirus, according to AFP. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded cautiously as the euphoria from the record highs on Wall St were soured by a significant jump in the number of additional coronavirus cases. The Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases under revised standards and 242 more deaths as of February 12th in which 13332 of the cases were made by clinical diagnosis. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.2%) remained afloat with a slew of earnings the main driver for the biggest movers in the index including Big 4 bank NAB and with TPG Telecom bolstered after the federal court approved its merger with Vodafone Hutchison Australia, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) succumbed to the flows into the JPY and as participants also digested quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were subdued amid uncertainty following the surge in confirmed cases and although some suggested the number would have been less than the prior day without the adjustments, the number of new fatalities more than doubled. Finally, 10yr JGBs were choppy amid the cautious risk tone and after the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.2tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities, did little to spur demand for the benchmark.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9785 vs. Exp. 6.9787 (Prev. 6.9718)

China replaced the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office head, while the Hubei Province Party Secretary and Wuhan Communist Party chief were also removed from duty. (Newswires)

China's Defence Ministry said it strongly condemned US actions on indictments against China military personnel related to the Equifax case, while it urged the US to correct its mistakes and rescind the indictments. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

As a reminder, UK PM Johnson will today announce his cabinet reshuffle, however, speculation suggests that changes are likely to be limited. (Newswires)

 

UK RICS Housing Survey (Jan) 17 vs. Exp. 3.0 (Prev. -2.0). (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY stalled after printing fresh 3-month highs above the 99.00 level where it met resistance to provide some much needed reprieve for EUR/USD which languished firmly below 1.0900, while GBP/USD was uneventful near the 1.2950 level and sandwiched in between a cluster of Hourly-MA levels. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slipped below 110.00 and antipodeans were also pressured as markets were spooked on the announcement of the surge in coronavirus cases, although the relevant pairs are off their lows amid the uncertainty from the coronavirus. In addition, there were comments from RBA Governor Lowe who continued to suggest a lack of urgency to loosen policy in which he noted that low interest rates are working but will take time and that they are not obsessed with getting inflation back to target in a hurry.

Bank of Canada Governor Poloz said the Canadian economy is in a pretty good place and suggested that lowering rates could increase risks from higher debt levels. (Newswires)

RBA Governor Lowe said outlook in Australia is improving but added that coronavirus is having an uncertain impact and noted that Chinese policy stimulus will be good for Australia. Furthermore, RBA Governor Lowe said low interest rates are working and are going to take time, while he added they are not obsessed with getting inflation back to target in a hurry. (Newswires)

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said the RBNZ has a genuine neutral bias but is open to review that in light of developments, while he added that the impact from coronavirus expected to be modest but will review it if travel restrictions are prolonged or virus is more widespread. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed overnight as oil prices consolidated after the downbeat risk tone triggered a mild pullback from the prior day’s firm gains in which WTI and Brent crude futures notched gains of more than 3% and 4% respectively in tandem with Wall St’s rally to fresh record highs. Nonetheless, the momentum has since petered out due to the coronavirus-related concerns, while participants also lie in wait for Russia’s response to the OPEC+ deal. Elsewhere, gold prices benefitted from a safe-haven bid but with upside capped as the greenback held near 3-month highs, while copper was marginally pressured after markets were spooked by the jump in additional coronavirus cases.

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said the senate should not vote for the Iran war powers resolution and suggested that the US is doing very well with Iran and this is not the time to show weakness, while he added that Iran would have a field day if his hands were tied which sends a very bad signal. (Newswires)

US 

The TPLEX bear steepened on Wednesday, ahead of Treasury supply with the T-Note seeing the most pronounced selling (compared to other maturities), as risk appetite continued to improve. Similar to Tuesday, the majority of the move happened in the overnight session, before finding its floor in early European trade. Desks note the selling was lead by real money as dealers sought concession ahead of the 10-year auction, in what was, more broadly, the most expensive since October. Nonetheless, the USD 27bln refunding auction was fairly decent, stopping through the 1.623% WI by 0.1bps, covered 2.58x (vs. six-auction average 2.41x), and dealers didn’t have to take down as much as usual, with both directs and indirects taking more than average. How much higher the 10-year yield can move in the near term remains up to debate, there are suggestions of algos/programme sellers “lurking” above 1.64% on the 10-year yield, a level which heavy gamma hedging took place last week, a level which could be tested if expectations move closer to that of a v-shaped recovery in the global economy post the coronavirus. By settlement, yields were higher across the curve with the 10-year yield at 1.63%, seeing the 2s10s widen by just under 1.5bps. US T-note futures (H20) settled 10 ticks lower at 130-22.

US Federal Budget (USD)(Jan) -33.0B vs. Exp. -11.5B (Prev. -13.3B). (Newswires)

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) are subdued amid uncertainty following the surge in confirmed cases and although some suggested the number would have been less than the prior day without the adjustments, the number of new fatalities more than doubled.

In FX markets, the DXY stalled after printing fresh 3-month highs above the 99.00 level where it met resistance to provide some much needed reprieve for EUR/USD which languishes firmly below the 1.0900 handle after the recent dismal Industrial Production data, while GBP/USD is uneventful near the 1.2950 level and sandwiched in between a cluster of Hourly-MA levels. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slipped below 110.00 and antipodeans were also pressured as markets were spooked on the announcement of the surge in coronavirus cases, although the relevant pairs are off their lows as the uncertainty spurs broad cautiousness. In addition, there were comments from RBA Governor Lowe who continued to suggest a lack of urgency to loosen policy as he noted that low interest rates are working but will take time and that they are not obsessed with getting inflation back to target in a hurry.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are choppy amid the cautious risk tone and with the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.2tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities, doing little to spur demand for the benchmark.

subject: PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th
content:
Great Wall Motor (2333 HK) - Co. January vehicle sales fell 28.2% Y/Y to 80.3k units. (Newswires)

HKT Trust (6823 HK) - Co. FY19 net HKD 5.22bln vs. Exp. HKD 5.22bln. (Newswires)

MGM China (2282 HK) - Co. FY19 adj. EBITDA HKD 6.2bln vs. Prev. HKD 4.8bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Xiaomi (1819 HK) - Co. guides FY19 revenue to exceed CNY 200bln. (Newswires)

MSCI - MSCI announced its index changes in which the 3 largest additions to indexes in which the 3 largest additions to its MSCI Emerging Markets Index were People’s Insurance Co, Wingtech Technology and Luckin Coffee. (Newswires)

Other News - Hong Kong Monetary Authority pledged to ensure the stability of the city’s financial system. (Newswires)

 

Coronavirus

China's Hubei province reported 14840 new coronavirus cases and 242 additional deaths as of February 12th, in which 13332 of the cases were clinical diagnosis and figures are under revised standards. Furthermore, reports noted Hubei authorities began using CT scans to test and diagnose patients amid shortages of RNA test kits and today’s case count includes cases diagnosed via CT scans for the first time. (Newswires/Twitter)

China Education Ministry officials said educational authorities will stagger the return of students to limit transmission of coronavirus. (Newswires)

WHO said the number of newly confirmed coronavirus cases has declined steadily for the past week but added that it must be interpreted with extreme caution and that the outbreak could still go in any direction. (Newswires)

CDC said it is seeing "fewer and fewer" travellers from China and no new cases at US airports, while it added new controls to avoid testing mishaps with the coronavirus and is likely to see some "community spread" in the US. (Newswires)

China's Communist Party Standing Committee is to implement prudent monetary policy including differentiated virus-curbing measures, while it is to enhance the strength of macro-policy adjustments, according to State TV. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin does not expect the coronavirus to have an impact on economic growth beyond this year, while he talked with Fed Chair Powell on the global economic impact of coronavirus and agreed it's too soon to say what the impact will be. Furthermore, Mnuchin added that the implementation of the mini-trade deal with China has slowed down due to the nCoV and that the entire "chapters" of Phase Two have been "dealt with". (Newswires)
